body:
Well, I think we need to figure out what sort of drag and drop behavior we want in the Qt console.

**Current behavior:**
- Text selections anywhere in the Qt console window or any other window can be dragged and dropped. If the location of the cursor at the time the text is dropped is in the current editable cell the text is inserted at the cursor location, otherwise the drop event is ignored.
- Files may not be dropped.

**Desired behavior:**
- Drag and drops of text selections should remain as they currently function. (No changes)
- Files should insert their filename (which @Carreau gave some good reasons why).  Dropping multiple files should result in all of their paths joined with spaces.  _Q:_ Should the filenames be inserted at the cursor location before the drag was started, or at the cursor location when the drop event happens?

> Q: Should the filenames be inserted at the cursor location before the drag was started, or at the cursor location when the drop event happens?

Cursor location IIF you can give a visual feedback. like a red cursor moving with the mouse...

For multiple files, as a list of string seem more practical no ?

Side question, can you show a menu at drop that ask `as spaces separated path`, `as a list of string` for multiple file ? (But I guess it will start to be annoying at some point if it always pop up...)

> Cursor location IIF you can give a visual feedback. like a red cursor moving with the mouse...

Do you know how to force the cursor to draw?  I can update the cursor location but by default it won't draw unless that window is the frontmost.  (You can see if if you start the drag and then use <kbd>command</kbd>-<kbd>tab</kbd> to bring the IPython Qt console to the front).  I didn't see any options in the Qt reference to show the cursor always.

I'm inclined to say the drop should go at the cursor location before the
drag started, anyway. It gives you a much larger target to hit.
let's go for cursor location before the drag started, it's simpler and enough.

On the other hand if you assume that in most cases the desired drop point is at the end of the current entry cell then the drop target is quite large as you can aim anywhere below or to the right of that line.

I guess the real issue is whether text drops should behave differently than file drops.

Okay I've split this up into two commits.  The first should replicate the existing drag and drop behavior by using the actual drag and drop events. The second is the new behavior for filenames.

I've changed the file drop behavior to always insert the filename at the cursor position before the drag was started (i.e., we don't update the text cursor position during the drag).  This seems reasonable to me.

The last issue we still need to sort out is the format of the filenames.  A regular terminal, for example, escapes the filenames (e.g., `' '` -> `'\ '`) and inserts multiple filenames separated by a space.  I'm leaving more towards something like  `", ".join(map(repr, filenames))` in Python.  What are your thoughts?
I prefer `", ".join(map(repr, filenames))` than `'\ '`

I agree.  One issue though.  I would want a command like 

```
In []: %load 
             ^-- drop file here
```

to be workable.

If we use `repr` it turns into

```
In []: %load u'/path/to/test.py'
```

which does not work.

But if we could remove the `u` it would work:

```
In []: %load '/path/to/test.py'
```

What's the "best" way to handle this unicode issue?

is it specific to %load ? 
We might want to patch %load ...

Well, rather any magic function is unlikely to be able to handle a unicode type string `u"..."` and know what to do with it.

I guess we could encode the filename via something like

``` python
repr(filename.encode(sys.getfilesystemencoding()))
```

**Edit:** No, this won't work either.  Hmf.

Okay, I seem to have settled on the following to properly quote the string.  It's more or less what `pipes.quote` does but applied to all strings instead of only strings with non-ascii characters.

``` python
text = ', '.join("'" + f.replace("'", "'\"'\"'") + "'"
                 for f in filenames)
```

## Status

### Platforms

I have only performed manual testing on the following platforms.
1. OS X 10.8, EPD 7.3
2. Ubuntu 12.04, (Python 2.7.3)
3. Ubuntu 12.04, (Python 3.2.3)

### Verification

I have verified the following drag and drop events.
1. Drag and drop of text from within the application continues to work as before.
2. Drag and drop of text from outside the application works.  Text is inserted at the location of the mouse cursor at the drop.
3. Drag and drop of files from outside the application works.  Filenames are "posix quoted", joined with `', '`, and inserted at the text cursor location when the drag was started.  The quoted format is compatible with both `open(...)` and `%run ...` for both standard ascii filenames, unicode filenames, and filenames containing quotes (e.g., `ᛦᛚᚳᚢᛗ'".py`).

Here is part of a sample log from one session:

``` python
In [12]: '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'"'"'".py'
Out[12]: '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/\xe1\x9b\x97\xe1\x9b\x81\xe1\x9a\xb3\xe1\x9b\x9a\xe1\x9a\xa2\xe1\x9a\xbe\'".py'

In [13]: print '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'"'"'".py'
/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'".py

In [14]: %run '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'"'"'".py'
Hello

In [15]: open('/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'"'"'".py').read()
Out[15]: 'print("Hello")\n'

In [16]: files = '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/ᛗᛁᚳᛚᚢᚾ'"'"'".py', '/home/bfroehle/Desktop/TODO.txt'
```

### Todo

Manual testing should be done in a Windows environment.  In particular we should check that files with unicode names and containing quotes are inserted in a usable form.

In addition we should test in Python 3.

On Mon, Aug 13, 2012 at 11:44 AM, Bradley M. Froehle <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Manual testing should be done in a Windows environment.

@jdmarch, @jstenar: any chance you guys could let us know if this is
robust?  In particular, given how much Enthought uses the Qt machinery on
Windows, we should wait for confirmation from at least @jdmarch that it's
OK with their stuff.

But many thanks Brad for tackling this super-thorny problem!
Looks like a great effort. We will check it ASAP -- lots on the plate right now.

On Mon, Aug 13, 2012 at 1:32 PM, Jonathan March notifications@github.comwrote:

> Looks like a great effort. We will check it ASAP -- lots on the plate
> right now.

No rush, many thanks!

I've rebased this onto the current master.  In addition I've done some manual testing in Python 3 on Linux and haven't encountered any bugs.

I think we are only waiting for confirmation that there aren't any issues in Windows.  Verification instructions are a [few posts ago](#issuecomment-7702994).
This pull request [passes](http://travis-ci.org/ipython/ipython/builds/2296482) (merged 628e3844 into 0af1e9d0).
Rebased again.  Still waiting for some testing in Windows.
I would vote in favor to merge so that people will test on windows because they have no choices.
@Carreau, @bfroehle, @fperez  -- sorry for the delay, testing on Windows now.
No problem. We know that it's difficult to test with the high number of opened PRs.

In vanilla qtconsole in Win XP, text drag n drop is fine. Filename drop does not work when path includes separators, because the filenames are in single quotes rather than double. (Filename handling remains a mess in Windows ipython, but double-quoted filenames are more robust than single-quoted ones, c.f. #1123). Example pertinent to this PR:

```
In [4]: run "~/hello.py"
hello

In [5]: run '~/hello.py'
ERROR: File `u'~/hello.py'` not found.
```

Any reason not to use double quotes for filename dnd?
I'm not currently set up to test this with an embedded qtconsole, but have asked colleagues to do so. Hopefully they will be able to merge without trouble.

> Any reason not to use double quotes for filename dnd?

Yes, I think it was a conscious decision to match pipes.quote.  I think it makes escaping the characters simpler in posix systems.

I'll look at your linked issue.

All these Windows issues seem to stem from the fact that we split arguments posix-ly in POSIX systems, and non-posix-ly in windows.

See [IPython.core.magic.Magics.parse_options](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/core/magic.py#L604).

I guess the resolution is that we need a "posix" quote and a "non-posix" quote function?  Or else we can start tearing down these posix/non-posix walls.

@jdmarch @bfroehle @fperez -- Extremely sorry for the delay in testing this out.  

I've tested it, and the changes look good to me.  Things work fine for me on Windows.  There was a minor problem Ubuntu (KDE).  I'll leave a comment on the related lines.
@punchagan Okay thanks!  I've incorporated your changes and rebased onto the current master branch.  Can you check it out again?
@bfroehle Thanks for changing it.  It works fine, now!

For what it's worth I think we should commit this, even with the admittedly poor `%run` handling for dropped files in Windows.

It's not a regression, since file drops were not supported previously, and it's a nice improvement in other platforms (mac, linux).
